title: 103_hr3767
content: The "HOME Investment Partnerships Act Amendments of 1994" allows state agencies or instrumentalities to participate in affordable housing programs. It also simplifies income targeting for rental housing programs. Section 214(1) of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to specify that families receiving rental assistance or dwelling units occupied by families with certain incomes are eligible for assistance. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to allow rental assistance for families with certain incomes or occupied by such households. SEC. 4. Changes to homeownership units include removing the first-time homebuyer requirement and simplifying resale provisions. SEC. 5. Stabilization of funding thresholds. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to remove certain paragraphs in sections 216 and 217, and adjust allocation criteria for participating jurisdictions receiving $500,000 or more. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to remove paragraphs in sections 216 and 217 and adjust allocation criteria for participating jurisdictions receiving $500,000 or more. Additionally, changes are made to paragraph (9)(B) by removing a specific clause. SEC. 6. COMPREHENSIVE AFFORDABLE HOUSING STRATEGY. The Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include a requirement for a current housing affordability strategy approved by the Secretary. The Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act is also amended to emphasize the importance of a housing affordability strategy. Assistance under subtitle B is contingent on compliance with a housing affordability strategy approved by the Secretary. Projects must align with the jurisdiction's housing affordability strategy to receive assistance under this title. Title IV of the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act is amended by removing and redesignating certain subparagraphs and paragraphs. SEC. 7. MATCHING REQUIREMENTS. Each participating jurisdiction must contribute at least 25 percent of funds drawn from the HOME Investment Trust Fund to affordable housing. SEC. 8. SEPARATE AUDIT REQUIREMENT. Section 283 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to require audits by the Comptroller General. SEC. 283. Audits by Comptroller General are amended, moving subsections and striking sentences. SEC. 9. Environmental review. Section 288 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include provisions for monitoring environmental reviews, training for such reviews, and criteria for suspension or termination of assumption. The Secretary's duty under this subsection does not limit any responsibility assumed by a State or unit of general local. Section 288 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include provisions for monitoring environmental reviews, training, and criteria for suspension or termination of assumption. This amendment clarifies the responsibilities of jurisdictions, Indian tribes, and insular areas in the process. The amendment to the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 allows for the use of CDBG funds for administrative expenses and project delivery costs related to the HOME program under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. SEC. 11. Matching requirement under HOPE III program amended from 33 percent to 25 percent. SEC. 12. Flexibility of CDBG program for disaster areas includes suspension of requirements. The Secretary may suspend requirements for disaster areas declared by the President under the Stafford Act, except for specific conditions related to funding, nondiscrimination, fair housing, labor, environmental standards, and benefiting low- and moderate-income individuals.
